Lesson 1: Income Statement

Income Statement

Revenue - Expenses = Net Income

Income statements show how much money a business made and spent over a period of time. They may be referred to as a statement of activities or a profit and loss statement.

By identifying the sources and uses of funds for a business, an income statement shows what is actually earned and what it costs to earn that amount. Income statements can be prepared annually, monthly, or at other intervals during the year. An income statement is usually required by most lending institutions.

Instructions: Select each dropdown below to take a closer look at what income statements include and why they are important.

  • Components

    Image by Monstera Production under Pexels modified from the original

    An income statement will always include:

    1. Revenue: funds received including tuition, fees, grants, subsidy money, fundraising, etc.
    2. Expenses: funds spent including rent, utilities, supplies, payroll, taxes, etc.

    3. Net Income: The amount of money earned after accounting for expenses (revenue minus expenses and taxes). Also referred to as:

      • The “bottom line”
      • “Profit” if the number is positive
      • “Loss” if the number is negative

      *Be aware: Net income may not match the amount of cash in the bank because of timing. You may count something as “revenue” that hasn’t been cashed or paid yet or as an “expense” for a bill that hasn’t been paid or a check that has yet to be cashed.

    An income statement may feel familiar to you because it is very similar to a budget. Both show revenue, expenses, and the bottom line. While the budget is a plan, the income statement shows what actually happened.

  • Purpose

    Image by Monstera Production under Pexels modified from the original

    An income statement tells how much money your program earned and spent during a period of time (a month, a quarter, a fiscal year*, etc.). It shows your bottom line, which demonstrates whether your business is breaking even, profitable, or running at a loss.

    *Remember, a fiscal year represents a 12-month period of time used for tax or accounting purposes. It does not necessarily follow the calendar year.

  • Importance

    Image by Karolina Grabowska under Pexels

    The income statement is a necessary tool to support making informed financial and management decisions, especially if you are running at a loss. You will likely use your budget in tandem with the income statement to reassess projected and actual revenue and expenses and see where you need to change or continue course.

    Income statements can prove especially useful when used to compare current information against another similar time period, for example prior years to the current year. This comparison allows you to more easily identify unusual differences that require further review.

    Finally, lenders want to know that a business has a history of running at a profit. Your income statements will be the evidence to prove that your business is worth the investment.

Examples

Let’s take a look at a more detailed income statement below. Notice the structure of this report. An income statement will always show revenue at the top, followed by expenses below, and then the net income at the bottom.

Example Income Statement

Small Explorers Child Care Center Statement of Activities for Twelve-Month Period Ended June 30, 2023
Revenue Amount
Parent Fees $240,400
Infant-Toddler Grant 145,000
Subsidy Programs 175,750
CACFP 45,000
Fundraising 15,000
Total Revenue $621,150
Expenses Amount
Payroll $334,500
Taxes and Benefits 62,463
Classroom/Office Supplies 32,000
Advertising 2,100
Food 50,000
Travel 776
Facility Repair 1,900
Insurance 15,000
Holiday Party 500
Rent/Lease 100,000
Professional Services 2,000
Utilities 11,325
Phone 2,400
Fundraising 2,000
Total Expenses $616,964
Net Income Amount
Net Income $4,186

Check Your Understanding

Instructions: How does this income statement demonstrate this business is operating? Using the dropdown, select a profit, a loss, breaking even, or not enough information to tell. Select the Submit Answer button to submit your answer.


Based on this income statement alone, Small Explorers operated at a profit in fiscal year 2023 because their net income was positive $4,186.

Comparative Income Statements

While a single income statement can tell you whether or not you are breaking even, generating a profit, or operating at a loss, its use is limited, especially if it covers a short amount of time. To make this report a more valuable management tool, it’s important to show a comparison between two time periods so that you can identify variance between them. For example, the abbreviated sample report below shows a comparison of the current month to the same month in the prior year.

Comparative Income Statement Example

Income statement for the Period Ending September 30, 2023
Revenue As of 9/30/2023 As of 9/30/2022 Variance
Tuition/Parent Fees 12,400 11,900 500
Child Care Subsidies 5,600 4,700 900
Child and Adult Care Food Program 2,000 3,700 -1,700
Total Revenue 20,000 20,300 -300
Expense As of 9/30/2023 As of 9/30/2022 Variance
Employee Payroll and Taxes 12,500 10,500 2,000
Rent 5,000 4,750 250
Utilities 400 180 220
Repairs and Maintenance 3,000 50 2,950
Total Expense 20,900 15,480 5,420
Net Income As of 9/30/2023 As of 9/30/2022 Variance
Net Income -900 4,820 -5,720

Consider what you can learn from this comparison. What story do the numbers tell? Let’s look at total revenue first. From September 2022 to September 2023, revenue was close to equal with just $300 difference. But when we look down to net income, our sample center is taking a loss of $900 this month. Even worse, that’s a $5,720 difference from September of last year!

Check Your Understanding

Instructions: What could explain the difference in net income? Using the dropdown, select an employee payroll and taxes increased, rent increased, utilities increased, repairs and maintenance increased, or all four expense categories increased. Select the Submit Answer button to submit your answer.


All four expense categories increased is correct. There has been a significant increase in all four categories of expenses this September compared to last September even though revenue has remained consistent.

Variance Cause Determination

Once you identify variance to know where things are different, you can look into what caused the difference and decide if there is something that needs attention or action. If we take a closer look, we can start to identify some small and big changes that made an enormous impact on the bottom line.

  1. Employee Payroll: Employees got a small hourly wage increase consistent with a cost of living increase that cost $2,000 more this month than last September.
  2. Rent: The landlord bumped the cost of rent.
  3. Utilities: The cost of utilities more than doubled without any clear explanation. This will be a variance that needs more investigation.
  4. Repairs and Maintenance: Comparing costs, this September cost $2,950 more than last year because some parts of the playground needed to be repaired and replaced. Because this income statement is a monthly report, it doesn’t show that this expense has been accounted for in the total yearly budget.

Without comparing our two income statements, we might wrongly assume that our sample center is spending frivolously. But by exploring variance, we can better understand what the numbers mean and if we need to take action.

Application

Instructions: Using what you've learned and what you know about this sample center, consider the following next steps for helping the center get back on track. Using the dropdowns select Options A, B, C, D, or E. Select each Check Answer button to check your answer.

What course of action would you recommend?

Option A Ensure all tuition and fees have been billed and paid.

Option B Review CACFP to better understand the variance. Are there any available scholarships you aren’t receiving? Is all the paperwork correct?

Option C Figure out the large difference in utilities. Is there a mistake in the bill? Are lights or air units getting left on at night?

Option D Review the budget to actual and see where things line up (and don’t). Adjust accordingly to break even next month.

Option E All of the above.


All of these steps would be helpful, acknowledging that you are working with somewhat limited information. There could be multiple solutions that could make a difference for our sample center.

What other comparisons would be helpful for determining next steps?

Option A Current year‐to‐date to the same period last year.

Option B Current month to last month (if you would be expecting similar results).

Option C Each month of the current year side-by-side (for example, Jan, Feb, Mar, April, May) to see how things have changed from month to month and identify trends or anomalies.

Option D Budget to actual (income statement) to help you see what you planned (budget) and what actually happened (actuals) comparing the same period of time.

Option E All of the above.


All of these reports could be helpful. A variety of reports could give you greater context and help you understand the deeper meanings behind variance.

Experience and practice will help you continue to improve your skills and knowledge about finance. You are putting in the work and it will pay off in the long run. Great job!
